sentences.english: You look a bit tatty in these clothes.
sentences.chinese: 你穿着這些衣服看上去有點寒磣。

sentences.english: You look rather shabby in those rags.
sentences.chinese: 你穿那件衣服顯得很寒磣。

sentences.english: Although she has become a celebrity, she still maintains an extremely frugal and sparing life.
sentences.chinese: 儘管她已成爲名人，卻仍然過着拮据寒磣的生活。

sentences.english: First his humble little shop became a smart one.
sentences.chinese: 先是他那寒磣的小店變得面目一新了。

sentences.english: Without a dress handkerchief, I felt underdressed.
sentences.chinese: 我沒有禮服手帕，自覺寒磣。

definition: lit. chickens flying and dogs jumping (idiom)/fig. in chaos/in disarray
to step down gracefully (humble expression)/to concede defeat/to play second fiddle
to take advantage of one's position to bully people (idiom)/to kick people around
lit. to shoot from both sides (idiom)/fig. to display ambidexterity/to slap with one hand and then the other, in quick succession/to use both feet equally (football)
spendthrift and foolish/sb with more money than sense
lit. not even the chickens and dogs are left undisturbed (idiom)/fig. great commotion/pandemonium

lit. to assess the head and discuss the feet (idiom); minute criticism of a woman's appearance/fig. to find fault in minor details/to remark upon a person's appearance/nitpicking/overcritical/judgmental
